subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Milligan poems
msgSnippet: ... Well, we ve had a lot of practice recognizing funky spellings.  But wouldn t you be confused if you saw instructions telling you to erect the latter ?  Or
messageBody:
pgabhart scripsit:

> I may be abysmally ignorant of the extent of English dialects, but I
> suspect that for a very large majority of English speakers, i.e. the
> ones clustered in the middle of the bell curve of English pronunciation,
> we could get along just fine without a standardized spelling because the
> majority of the words we use on a daily basis are not going to be spelt
> so peculiarly by someone from a different, but still one of the major
> speech communities that it would not be recognizable.

Well, we've had a lot of practice recognizing funky spellings. But
wouldn't you be confused if you saw instructions telling you
to "erect the latter"? Or to "lie down on the caught"? Or to
"beware the wapses"? Or "not to make an abbot of it"?
Or "take a rod"? Or "catch the furry"? Or "sit on the cheer"?
or "climb the tire [or "tar"]"? How about being sent to where
the "paw people" live? Or "pull the card in emergencies"?
Or "hand me that pin, please"?

And yet all these mergers are found in the ordinary speech of
native speakers of English (though not all of them in
any one person, to be sure).

--
If you have ever wondered if you are in hell, John Cowan
it has been said, then you are on a well-traveled http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
road of spiritual inquiry. If you are absolutely cowan@...
sure you are in hell, however, then you must be
on the Cross Bronx Expressway. --Alan Feuer, NYTimes, 2002-09-20

Or "take a rod"?  Or "catch the furry"?  Or "sit on the cheer"?
or "climb the tire [or "tar"]"?  How about being sent to where

Or "hand me that pin, please"?

And yet all these mergers are found in the ordinary speech of
native speakers of English (though not all of them in
any one person, to be sure).
